data.title: Indexing... problems
data.body:
Description:

Cmd-t never lists any files, just shows Indexing... forever.

Steps to reproduce:
- Check out a repo
- run script/bootstrap
- open the project in atom.

I'm running on master as of last thursday or so, currently on slow hotel wifi that precludes updating CEF and clean && build from scratch.. 

For what it's worth, @atmos isn't having the same problem using an older atom. This could maybe be due to something else specific to my dev machine? If so, I could use some help diagnosing it so that we can maybe get some useful information about the behavior.

data.title: This is a cleanup of the whitespace package.
data.body:
StripTrailingWhitespace package renamed to Whitespace (and other changes). I created a pull request so people with `config.stripTrailingWhitespace.singleTrailingNewline` will take notice.

Closes #399

data.title: Add git diff package
data.body:
I wanted to keep learning about the extension creation process; I thought a git diff tool might be nice to add to the core packages. Diffs are done between whatever is committed in `HEAD` versus whatever is currently on disk.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-31 at 5 48 43 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/64050/322638/775b299c-9a66-11e2-96f3-6e4f7403a6e7.png)

This is still very much a work in progress, mostly around UX and how the changes should be represented. I need a little help on panel-splitting and editor creating. Unlike `MarkdownPreview`, I don't think this diff should split into its own window, and should instead act as an "overlay" for the current file.  Ideally I'd love to mimic GitHub's own diff view with two gutters, one for the original lines and another for the changed.

data.title: Right clicking on a misspelled word should show a context menu of suggested words
Ideas for forking npm into an "apm"
data.body:
npm has the option to specify a registry for where packages are looked up: https://npmjs.org/doc/registry.html

Alternate registries can be set permanently, or on each call with the `--registry` option.

We could bundle `apm` with Atom (or keep it internal to the editor). This would just be a call to `npm --registry <our_repository>`.

Running your own npm registry is as simple as setting up CouchDB somewhere! As far as I can tell, here are some pretty dang detailed instructions: http://clock.co.uk/tech-blogs/how-to-create-a-private-npmjs-repository

We could also be cleverer and mandate that all Atom packages are git repos hosted on GitHub. It might make life for developers simpler; a "package" is just whatever the default branch is, and appropriate files are `.gitignore`d from a users' machine.

At any rate, rather than have devs register another username for another service, I think it'd be great to associate Atom packages they've contributed with their username, for extra nerd cred.

data.title: can't set the cursor on the last line of a file
data.body:
![assets go - _Users_rick_github_api-uploader](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/21/314293/47fc97fe-97c7-11e2-851e-05cdfff503d8.png)

So I can click far to the right of line 78 to get the curser after that `}`.  Can't seem to do it on line 79 unless I add an extra blank line at the end.  

Though @rtomayko told me once I should add that extra line anyway (for unix tools like `cat` or whatever).  That's fine, but when I run into this it takes me 30s to figure out why shit isn't working :)

data.title: technoweenie wishlist
data.body:
Hey guys, I'm loving Atom.  I'm still using vim for github/github, but smaller projects are working well in Atom.
- [x] Ability to open a tab from the fuzzy finder.
  I do this in Vim's ctrlp plugin all the time.  
  1. ctrl-t to open the fuzzy finder
  2. find the file
  3. open it!
     - ctrl-t opens the file in a new tab
     - ctrl-v opens the file in a new vertical split
     - enter opens the file normally
  
  My flow in Atom is more like:
  1. cmd-t opens the fuzzy finder
  2. find the file
  3. open the file
  4. vertical split file
  5. close opened file in original tab
- [ ] Pasting code snippets seems to be funky.  I can't really put a finger on it, and realize it is a tough problem.  I think I'm used to vim trying to keep things indented cleanly.

data.title: Meta-shift-click and drag for column/box selection
data.body:
Column/box selection. Basically this creates a selection per line to allow editing on multiple lines at the same time.

In the specs it works, however when actually using it, once it goes over two or three lines of selections the editor gets really slow, so probably I'm doing something wrong or not quite right.

data.title: --wait should not auto-focus the next open window but return to where it was opened from
data.body:
My scenario to explain my problem:

I have Atom open editing. I commit changes and then `--amend` with `EDITOR="atom --wait"`. When I close the `COMMIT_MSG` file to return to the terminal, it automatically focuses the next open Atom window instead of going back to the terminal.

Not sure if that's possible, but I was expecting to go back to the Terminal window I had open before to continue.

data.title: Nak powered search
data.body:
> nak blah blah no native components blah blah fast.

In addition to swapping out `ag`, this PR introduces more huzzahs:
- Streaming search results. `populateSingle` is called each time the `BufferedProcess` gets another chunk of information. (This is guaranteed to always be a path followed by the results, so there's no risk of lost information.)
- The fuzzy file finder now implements `nak` as well. It takes about a second to perform a full retrieve on `~/github/github`, without includes. (The dir-walker I wrote is actually the fastest part, and you can also set up file/dir ignores.)
- By default, `nak` includes your ignore files. `config.set(nak.addVCSIgnores, true)` if you need them excluded.

My questions:
- I'm not particularly proud of `project.previewList = @previewList` in _command-panel-view.coffee_, but I didn't know how else to pass the previewList object to _select-all-matches-in-project.coffee_.
- There's a lot of leftover `@operations` crud in _preview-list.coffee_--should I get rid of it? I didn't know if it did anything else.
- I don't know how to run the tests :crying_cat_face:. `rake test` started downloading the `node` tar and that seemed like a waste of time.
- In addition to _.gitignore_, you can also set up a _.nakignore_. That's not in the code here but it's something to consider.

data.title: Failing test for selectLine issue
data.body:
I think calling select-line n times would cause it to select the next n lines, however it looks like it only selects the current line. I looked into solving this but I don't yet fully understand how selections work internally.

I included a failing test in the pull request. Let me know if this is a bug or how select-line should behave.

data.title: fs callbacks no longer fired
data.body:
This happened yesterday, callbacks for fs methods stopped firing. It appeared though that child process callbacks were still firing.

It only happened once and the CPU appeared to be at 100% at the time.

/cc @zcbenz @nathansobo

data.title: Streamline packages
data.body:
This PR improves the API for loading, activating, and deactivating packages.
- Packages can be activated or deactivated by name at any time, decoupled from the startup of the window.
- We initially don't activate any packages, and specs that depend on certain packages being loaded need to activate those packages themselves.
- Any active packages are always deactivated at the end of each spec, leaving us with a clean environment.
- When a package is deactivated, its keymaps, grammars, stylesheets, properties, etc are all removed from the global environment.
- Packages are loaded only once, then cached from there on out. Loading a package has no side effects. It just performs the I/O necessary to load all its resources, which are later installed when the package is activated.

data.title: Load TextMate grammars with async I/O instead of a worker thread
data.body: This isn't quite how I'd like it because it still emits a global 'grammars-loaded' event after all the packages have been loaded. It uses a queue to serialize the loading of each package's grammars, then emits this event when the queue is empty. Instead, I'd like to fire an event every time a grammar is added and have a `LanguageMode` switch to that grammar if it is a better match. Then any time a grammar is added we can respond appropriately with the currently open edit sessions. But I want to clean up package loading first so this was a good way to get this merged to master now.

data.title: WIP: Ui kit
data.body:
I have a few ideas for other packages, and most require some form of custom UI.

To make it easier for plugin authors to build a UI and not have to start from scratch, this will provide a simple API for creating Dialogs.

data.title: Add ProcessTask
data.body:
ProcessTask is equivalent to Task except that ProcessTask starts a new process instead of a new thread.

ProcessTask is using child_process.fork to start a new node process to start the task, the node binary used by ProcessTask is built with the V8 shipped by Chromium, so native modules compiled for cefode is compatible with the node binary.

/cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo

data.title: We have node now, so kill our path module
meta-d doesn't work on the first line of a wrapped line
data.body:
Given this wrapped document with a long line:

```
1  
2 yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo 
 yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo yo 
3
```

Focusing line 2 and hitting `meta-d` does nothing. Focusing the second half of line 2 (indicated by the ) and hitting `meta-d` deletes the whole line.

`meta-d` works as expected if the long line is the first line in the document, but seems to fail if it's anywhere else.

data.title: OS X dictionary doesn't work
data.body:
Usually you can highlight a word in OS X and hit `cmd-ctrl-d` to see its definition but this doesn't work in Atom.

data.body: Coffee and CSON files are pre-compiled, less files should probably be as well.
